item.title: Israel Resumes Offensive in Gaza Strip After Truce With Hamas Ends
item.description: Talks on extending a weeklong cease-fire broke down, with each side blaming the other. The truce had included the release of hostages held in Gaza for people in Israeli prisons.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ben Hubbard and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourned relatives on Friday at a funeral in Khan Younis, in Gaza’s south.

item.title: COP 28 Climate Summit: Global Warming Talks Begin Amid Deep Tensions
item.description: World leaders spoke in Dubai against a backdrop of rising temperatures and two major wars.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Heads of state and government will be speaking at the COP28 summit in Dubai on Friday and Saturday.

item.title: A Russian Village Buries a Soldier, and Tries to Make Sense of the War
item.description: In Russia, the pain and loss of the war in Ukraine are felt most profoundly in small villages, where a soldier’s burial produces not just grief but a yearning to find meaning in his death.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral for Garipul S. Kadyrov, a Russian soldier who was killed while fighting in Ukraine, in the village of Ovsyanka, Russia, this month.

item.title: Alleged Plot to Kill Sikh Separatist Highlights Thorn in India’s Side
item.description: The charges are rooted in a decades-old dispute over the demand by some Sikhs for a sovereign state known as Khalistan carved out of northern India.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Members of the Sikh community protesting against Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in Washington in 2020.

item.title: Israel’s Next Aim Is Southern Gaza. U.S. Urges Restraint.
item.description: American officials are making clear to Israel that it cannot pursue a campaign in the south that would have the same devastating consequences as in the north.
item.dc:creator: Yara Bayoumy and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City last month.

item.title: Dozens of Unclaimed Corpses Show That an Indian Conflict Continues
item.description: The government has tried to shift the focus. That’s harder with morgues still full of bodies six months after the start of ethnic violence in Manipur.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of ethnic clashes in Manipur in July. Minority Kukis have accused majority Meiteis of ethnic cleansing.

item.title: Russia Extends Detention of U.S. Journalist Alsu Kurmasheva
item.description: Alsu Kurmasheva, an editor who also holds Russian citizenship, was arrested in October on charges of failing to register as a foreign agent.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Alsu Kurmasheva, center, an editor at Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, at a court hearing in Kazan, Russia, on Friday. Her detention was extended to Feb. 5.

item.title: Israel Knew Hamas’s Attack Plan Over a Year Ago
item.description: A blueprint reviewed by The Times laid out the attack in detail. Israeli officials dismissed it as aspirational and ignored specific warnings.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Hamas-led gunmen seized an Israeli military vehicle after infiltrating areas of southern Israel during the Oct. 7 attacks. A blueprint for similar attacks was circulating among Israeli leaders long before Hamas struck.

item.title: Biden’s Bond With Modi, India’s Leader, Is Tested by Alleged Plot
item.description: The charges illustrate how complicated it can be for American presidents to balance their relationships with deeply imperfect allies.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Julian E. Barnes and Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India during a state dinner at the White House in June. Officials said they had no information that Mr. Modi was aware of the alleged plot.

item.title: Return to Haiti of a Coup Leader Raises Concerns of More Turmoil
item.description: Guy Philippe, who helped lead the coup that ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in 2004, is back in the politically unstable country after serving time in a U.S. prison.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Guy Philippe, a leader of the 2004 coup in Haiti, is taken off a bus at Haiti’s National Police station, in Port-au-Prince, after he was deported from the United States on Thursday.

item.title: How a Book Publishing ‘Mistake’ Reignited the U.K.’s Royal Racism Furor
item.description: The rollout of “Endgame” caused a scandal after a quickly withdrawn translation named family members said to have asked about the skin color of Prince Harry and Meghan’s future son.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Endgame: Inside the Royal Family and the Monarchy's Fight for Survival (Book)
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, in New York last month. She made the initial allegation in a 2021 interview with Oprah Winfrey.

item.title: An Alleged Plot’s Burning Question: Why Would India Take the Risk?
item.description: After an indictment accuses an Indian official of ordering an assassination on U.S. soil, diplomats and experts debate how far up the chain the scheme went.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: An indictment unsealed this week described a plot to kill a Sikh activist in New York, months after a Sikh leader was killed in Canada. Both called for the creation of a Sikh state.

item.title: Russia Asks Court to Label Gay Rights Movement as ‘Extremist’
item.description: Activists said the designation could put L.G.B.T.Q. people and their organizations under threat of criminal prosecution for something as simple as displaying the rainbow flag.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Russian police officers blocking L.G.B.T.Q. protesters in St. Petersburg in 2019.

item.title: Kenya Curbs Kenneth Kaunda’s Famous Suit
item.description: A favorite of President William Ruto, the suit was banned along with other traditional African attire for violating parliamentary dress codes. Proper attire, the speaker decreed, is a Western suit and tie.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Elizabeth Paton
item.media:description: President William Ruto and King Charles III at a naval base in Mombasa, Kenya, this month.

item.title: Cindy McCain, Head of World Food Program, Faces Staff Revolt Over Gaza Conflict
item.description: Staff members accused Ms. McCain, the W.F.P.’s leader, of not leveraging her position to speak out against the suffering of Palestinian civilians, and some have called for her removal.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Julien De Rosa
item.media:description: Cindy McCain, the director of the United Nation’s World Food Program, was appointed to her role earlier this year.

item.title: A protester self-immolates outside the Israeli Consulate in Atlanta.
item.description: A security guard tried to intervene but was unsuccessful, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Colbi Edmonds

item.title: Henri Lopes, 86, Who Straddled Literature and Politics in Africa, Dies
item.description: His lauded fiction satirized abuses of power in the continent, but as a high official for the Republic of Congo, he benefited from a much-criticized government.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: With the End of the Cease-Fire, Concern Grows Over the Oldest Israeli Hostages Left Behind
item.description: Going without medicines, proper nutrition and other necessities leave many especially vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman
item.media:description: Ditza Heiman, 84, on Tuesday in an ambulance at the Sheba Medical Center after arriving on an Israeli army helicopter. She was part of a group of hostages released this week.

item.title: Freed Palestinians Were Mostly Young and Not Convicted of Crimes
item.description: Israel has released a total of 240 Palestinian prisoners and detainees during a weeklong pause in hostilities.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao, Karen Zraick, Anushka Patil and Gaya Gupta

item.title: At P.S.G., a Coach’s Vision Collides With a Star’s Power
item.description: The system may be the center of the modern soccer universe, but stars like Kylian Mbappé exert a gravity of their own.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Kylian Mbappé, now P.S.G.’s unquestioned king.

item.title: Some Freed Hostages Are Now Learning of Loved Ones’ Deaths
item.description: More than any of them are now learning for the first time that their relatives were killed on Oct. 7 or are still being held hostage.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams, Katherine Rosman, Emma Bubola and Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Hostages and Missing Families Forum, via Associated Press

item.title: Blinken Blames Hamas for Breaking Truce With Israel
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state said he also believed Israel was taking steps in this next phase of war to protect civilian lives in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken before departing from Al Maktoum International Airport in Dubai on Friday.

item.title: Thief in Australia Steals Truck With 10,000 Krispy Kreme Doughnuts
item.description: A woman thought she was stealing a van. She got thousands of doughnuts as well.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Krispy Kreme doughnuts.

item.title: Surging U.S. Oil Production Brings Down Prices and Raises Climate Fears
item.description: American oil production is hitting record levels, delivering economic and foreign policy benefits but putting environmental goals further out of reach.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. oil producers are cranking out a record 13.2 million barrels a day, more than Russia and Saudi Arabia.

item.title: The truce broke down over the details of further hostage and prisoner exchanges, Israeli officials say.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: Smoke rising from Gaza while Israeli soldiers stand near the border with Gaza, in Israel, on Friday.

item.title: Israel had a blueprint for the Oct. 7 attacks a year ago. Officials dismissed it.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Hamas-led gunmen seized an Israeli military vehicle after infiltrating areas of southern Israel during the Oct. 7 attacks. A blueprint for similar attacks was circulating among Israeli leaders long before Hamas struck.

item.title: A Back Door to Taylor Swift’s Australia Tickets? Not if You’re in Australia.
item.description: An online reseller has skirted the country’s restrictions on ticket sales, allowing Swifties elsewhere to buy admission to the star’s Eras Tour.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fans during Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour in Buenos Aires in November.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A leaked document revealing details of Hamas’s Oct. 7 plot.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman running to a shelter in her home in Ashkelon, Israel, on Oct. 7.

item.title: Talks were continuing in hopes of reviving the truce.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Victoria Kim, Michael Crowley and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Reacting after an Israeli airstrike in the southern Gaza Strip on Friday.

item.title: Exactly How Much Life is on Earth?
item.description: According to a new study, living cells outnumber stars in the universe, highlighting the deep, underrated link between geophysics and biology.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Artem Povarov, Mike Rosecope/Alamy; NASA; ESA/Euclid Consortium
item.media:description: Researchers calculated that Earth has more living cells — a million trillion trillion, or a 1 followed by 30 zeros — than grains of sand.

item.title: Blinken Urges Israel to Reduce Civilian Deaths as More Hostages Are Freed
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Israeli officials and a Palestinian leader on Thursday to seek improved conditions for Gaza’s civilians and to try to exert influence over Israel’s expected military offensive.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant in Tel Aviv on Thursday.

item.title: When Henry Kissinger Became an Opera Character
item.description: In 1987, “Nixon in China” meditated on what was then recent history, depicting Kissinger as a smooth diplomat with a brutal side.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Woolfe
item.media:description: Richard Paul Fink, center in dark suit, as Henry Kissinger in “Nixon in China” at the Metropolitan Opera in 2011.

item.title: Alistair Darling, Guiding Hand in Britain’s Financial Crisis, Dies at 70
item.description: As the government’s chief financial cabinet member, he helped stave off a broader economic collapse amid the global turmoil set off in 2008
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:description: Alistair Darling in 2010. “Alistair was the person you would want in the room because he was calm and he was considered and he had great integrity,” said Gordon Brown, the Labour prime minister at the time.

item.title: What We Know About the Israeli Hostages Hamas Released on Thursday
item.description: Eight Israeli hostages were freed, including dual nationals from Mexico, Russia and Uruguay.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Hostages and Missing Families Forum, via Reuters
item.media:description: Mia Schem.

item.title: A Timeline of Plots Against Sikh Activists, According to Canada and the U.S.
item.description: Officials in the United States and Canada have described two assassination attempts: the killing of a Sikh leader in British Columbia and a plan to murder an activist in New York.
item.dc:creator: Derek M. Norman
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mourners carrying the coffin of Hardeep Singh Nijjar, a Sikh activist who was murdered in June in British Columbia.

item.title: Sikh Assassination Plot in NY Bolsters Canada’s Accusations Against India
item.description: An indictment in a plot against a Sikh separatist in the United States provides details in a killing that has strained relations between Canada and India.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada discussed allegations against the Indian government in September.

item.title: Friday Briefing: A New Climate Fund Approved
item.description: Plus the best albums of 2023.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: A home in Iranawila, Sri Lanka, that collapsed in June from coastal erosion.

item.title: Why Some Korean Basketball Players Love the Bank Shot
item.description: Banked free throws, an unorthodox technique, have a cult following in the Korean Basketball League.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeon Seong-hyen, a guard with the Goyang Sono Skygunners, making a free throw during the opening game of the season in Goyang, South Korea, in October in this composite image.

item.title: Emirati Fund to Invest Billions in U.S. Firms for Climate Projects
item.description: An Abu Dhabi fund is expected to invest at least $30 billion in climate projects with some of the biggest names in North American finance.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Sultan al Jaber, right, president of the U.N. climate conference, with Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, the U.A.E. president.

item.title: Henry Kissinger’s Life and Work in Photos
item.description: The U.S. diplomat rose from a bookish childhood in Germany to become a power player in the halls of American politics.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Henry Kissinger in Paris in 2006.

item.title: Climate Change Drives New Cases of Malaria, Complicating Efforts to Fight the Disease
item.description: The number of malaria cases rose again in 2022, propelled by flooding and warmer weather in areas once free of the illness.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A doctor tended to a malaria patient affected by flooding in a hospital in Sehwan, Pakistan, last year.

item.title: Kissinger’s Legacy Still Ripples Through Vietnam and Cambodia
item.description: His decision to authorize the bombing of Cambodia, efforts to extricate the U.S. from the Vietnam War and role in the rapprochement with China continue to be felt in Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: William Lovelace/Daily Express, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of a bombing in Snuol, Cambodia, during the Vietnam War, in May 1970.

item.title: Paul Whelan Attacked in Russian Prison, His Family Says
item.description: Mr. Whelan, who is serving a 16-year sentence in a labor camp, told his family that another inmate struck him in the face.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: The penal colony IK-17, where Paul Whelan, an American, has been serving out his sentence on espionage charges, in Mordovia, Russia.

item.title: Hostages Freed From Gaza Recount Violence, Hunger and Fear
item.description: Hostages who have returned to Israel in the past week have come home malnourished, ill, injured and bearing psychological wounds.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman, Emma Bubola, Rachel Abrams and Russell Goldman

item.title: COP28 Begins With Fossil Fuels, and Frustration, Going Strong
item.description: After decades of meetings, nations still haven’t agreed to curb the main driver of global warming.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Preparations underway for the opening of the United Nations Climate Summit in Dubai on Wednesday.

item.title: Where the World Is (and Isn’t) Making Progress on Climate Change
item.description: Emissions from electricity and transportation are projected to fall over time, a new report finds, but industry remains a major climate challenge.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Jerusalem Shooting Kills at Least 3 People, Israeli Officials Say
item.description: Israel’s Shin Bet security service said the gunmen were Palestinian brothers from East Jerusalem who were affiliated with Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Israeli officials working at the scene of a shooting on the outskirts of Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The U.N. climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden touring a wind turbine factory in Colorado, on Wednesday.

item.title: Henry Kissinger, Who Shaped U.S. Cold War History, Dies at 100
item.description: The most powerful secretary of state of the postwar era, he was both celebrated and reviled. His complicated legacy still resonates in relations with China, Russia and the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Neil Leifer/Sports Illustrated, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Henry A. Kissinger in 1979. He sought to strike and maintain balances of power in a dangerously precarious world.

item.title: Palestinian Activist Ahed Tamimi Freed From Israeli Prison in Hostage Exchange
item.description: The 22-year-old activist was jailed for three weeks without being charged. Her arrest was one of thousands made during the Israeli military’s crackdown in the occupied West Bank after the Hamas attacks on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: The recently freed Palestinian activist, Ahed Tamimi, center, with her mother, Nariman Tamimi, left, in the West Bank city of Ramallah early Thursday.

item.title: What We Know About Israeli Hostages Hamas Released on Wednesday
item.description: The sixth round of hostage releases since the cease-fire began involved 10 Israelis, four Thai nationals and two Israeli-Russian dual citizens.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin, Gaya Gupta, Rachel Abrams and Katherine Rosman
item.media:credit: Hostages and Missing Families Forum, via Reuters
item.media:description: Ra'aya Rotem

item.title: Britain Says Bye-Bye to Its Only Pandas as They’ll Soon Depart for China
item.description: The playful, waddling bears charmed millions of people at the Edinburgh Zoo of the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: A large panda seen in its enclosure at the Edinburgh Zoo in Britain in 2020. The country will return its pandas to China after about 12 years of having them as zoo residents.

item.title: Daisaku Ikeda, Who Led Influential Japanese Buddhist Group, Dies at 95
item.description: He grew Soka Gakkai International’s following over two decades and helped create a coalition partner for the country’s dominant Liberal Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Daisaku Ikeda in 1985. He led Soka Gakkai beginning in 1960 when he was 32 and broadened its reach to include more followers outside of Japan.

item.title: Pope’s Critics Feel the Sting After His Patience Runs Out
item.description: Vatican observers see a leader more willing to crack down on those seeking to derail his agenda for the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis watching circus performers spinning and flipping in front of him at his weekly general audience in the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Gaza Mediators Seek Cease-Fire Extension
item.description: Officials from Qatar, Egypt and the U.S. hope that a succession of pauses will pave the way toward a larger goal: bringing the war to a close.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: With a temporary cease-fire in effect, Gaza residents came out to look at the damage in Khan Younis on Wednesday.

item.title: Paris, 1919: History’s Slingshot
item.description: What happened in early 20th century Europe still propels much of modern politics, including the conflict in Gaza and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Delegates at the Paris Peace Conference, which led to the Treaty of Versailles, in 1919.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: A Race to Extend the Gaza Truce
item.description: Plus the U.S. charges an Indian man in an assassination plot.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Palestinians receive flour distributed by the United Nations on Wednesday in Khan Younis, Gaza, during a temporary truce between Hamas and Israel.

item.title: Google Agrees to Pay Canadian Media for Using Their Content
item.description: The Canadian government reached a deal with Google before a new law compelling tech giants to compensate news organizations comes into effect late next month.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Canadian Heritage Minister Pascale St-Onge speaking about a deal with Google, in Ontario, on Wednesday.

item.title: Government Offices in E.U. Can Ban Wearing of Religious Symbols
item.description: The bloc’s Court of Justice, ruling in the case of a female employee in Belgium who was told she could not wear a hijab in the office, said the restriction was lawful.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Hijabs for sale in Brussels in 2016. The Court of Justice of the European Union ruled on Tuesday that public-sector offices could bar workers from wearing religious garments such as head scarves.

item.title: Éric Dupond-Moretti, France’s Justice Minister, Is Cleared of Abuse of Power
item.description: Éric Dupond-Moretti was charged with using his position as a weapon to order investigations into four magistrates he had recently clashed with.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Justice Minister Éric Dupond-Moretti leaving the Paris courthouse after he was cleared of abuse of power on Wednesday.
